name: Don Omar
description:
'''William Omar Landrón Rivera'''{{Family name footnote|Landrón|Rivera|lang=Spanish}} (born February 10, 1978), known professionally as '''Don Omar''', is a Puerto Rican rapper, singer, songwriter, record producer, and actor. Dubbed the "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|King of Reggaeton]]" by music critics and fans alike, he has also been recognized by ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' and ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' as one reggaeton legend. He is often cited as an influence by other Hispanic urban performers.

Landrón was born in [[Santurce, San Juan, Puerto Rico|Santurce]], a neighborhood of [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]], Puerto Rico. He is one of the artists credited with presenting reggaeton to audiences around the world and having turned the musical genre into a global phenomenon. He jumped to stardom with the release of his first studio album, ''[[The Last Don (album)|The Last Don]]'', released in 2003. The album sold 411,000 units in the [[United States|US]] and was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). Since then, he has sold around 70 million records, making him [[List of best-selling Latin music artists|one of the best-selling Latin music artists]]. Has sold 100 billion units. On September 1, 2017, after a long musical career he announced that he would retire after a series of concerts at the [[José Miguel Agrelot Coliseum]] in Puerto Rico, scheduled to be held on December 15, 16 and 17. However, he returned to music on April 20, 2019, with his song single "Ramayama" featuring [[Farruko]].

During his career, Don Omar earned numerous [[List of awards and nominations received by Don Omar|accolades]], including three [[Latin Grammy Award]]s, one [[Billboard Music Awards|''Billboard'' Music Awards]], 17 [[Billboard Latin Music Awards|''Billboard'' Latin Music Awards]], three Lo Nuestro Awards, eight [[Viña del Mar International Song Festival|Viña del Mar International Song Festival Awards]], among others.

Don Omar has also portrayed Rico Santos in four films in the ''[[Fast & Furious]]'' franchise. He first played the character in 2009's ''[[Fast & Furious (2009 film)|Fast & Furious]]'' and then returned for ''[[Fast Five]]'' (2011), ''[[The Fate of the Furious]]'' (2017) and ''[[F9 (film)|F9]]'' (2021).
